A world without money would likely lead to a society that values bartering and exchange of goods and services based on need and availability, rather than monetary value. People would have to find alternative ways to acquire the things they need and want, such as trading skills or services with others, or relying on local communities for support.

Without money, people might become more creative and resourceful in finding ways to solve problems and create value. They would have to think outside the box and find new ways to produce, distribute, and consume goods and services. This could lead to a more innovative and dynamic economy.

The absence of money could also lead to a more equal society, as people would no longer be able to use it to buy power and influence. Decisions would be made based on consensus and mutual agreement, rather than on who has the most money.

Without money, people might have more time to pursue their passions and interests, as they would no longer be tied down by the need to work to earn a living. This could lead to a more fulfilling and meaningful life for individuals and society as a whole.

A world without money could also lead to a more sustainable and environmentally-friendly economy, as people would have to find ways to produce and consume goods and services that are in line with the limits of the natural world. This could result in a more circular and regenerative economy, where resources are used efficiently and waste is minimized.
